## [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#embassy-time)embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a [tick rate](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate) feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in `embassy-time` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of `(1 / tick_rate) seconds`.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#global-time-driver)Global time driver
The `time` module is backed by a global “time driver” specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use `embassy_time` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the [`embassy_time_driver`](https://crates.io/crates/embassy-time-driver) crate.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#instants-and-durations)Instants and Durations
[`Instant`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html "struct embassy_time::Instant") represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and [`Duration`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Duration.html "struct embassy_time::Duration") represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you’d expect, like addition and substraction.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#delays-and-timeouts)Delays and timeouts
[`Timer`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Timer.html "struct embassy_time::Timer") allows performing async delays. [`Ticker`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Ticker.html "struct embassy_time::Ticker") allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the `embedded-hal` delay traits is provided by [`Delay`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Delay.html "struct embassy_time::Delay"), for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#wall-clock-time)Wall-clock time
The `time` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time (“real life” datetimes like `2021-08-24 13:33:21`).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of `embassy_time` by storing the offset between “seconds elapsed since boot” and “seconds since unix epoch”.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#feature-flags)Feature flags
  * `defmt-timestamp-uptime` — Display the time since startup next to defmt log messages. At most 1 `defmt-timestamp-uptime-*` feature can be used. `defmt-timestamp-uptime` is provided for backwards compatibility (provides the same format as `uptime-us`). To use this you must have a time driver provided.
  * `mock-driver` — Create a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes.


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#generic-queue)Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate)Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.
Available tick rates:

## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#structs)

[Delay](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Delay.html "struct embassy_time::Delay")
    Type implementing async delays and blocking `embedded-hal` delays.

[Duration](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Duration.html "struct embassy_time::Duration")
    Represents the difference between two [Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html)s

[Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html "struct embassy_time::Instant")
    An Instant in time, based on the MCU’s clock ticks since startup.

[Ticker](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Ticker.html "struct embassy_time::Ticker")
    Asynchronous stream that yields every Duration, indefinitely.

[TimeoutError](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.TimeoutError.html "struct embassy_time::TimeoutError")
    Error returned by [`with_timeout`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_timeout.html "fn embassy_time::with_timeout") and [`with_deadline`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_deadline.html "fn embassy_time::with_deadline") on timeout.

[Timer](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Timer.html "struct embassy_time::Timer")
    A future that completes at a specified [Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html).
## Constants[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#constants)

[TICK_HZ](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/constant.TICK_HZ.html "constant embassy_time::TICK_HZ")
    Ticks per second of the global timebase.
## Traits[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#traits)

[WithTimeout](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/trait.WithTimeout.html "trait embassy_time::WithTimeout")
    Provides functions to run a given future with a timeout or a deadline.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#functions)

[block_for](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.block_for.html "fn embassy_time::block_for")
    Blocks for at least `duration`.

[with_deadline](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_deadline.html "fn embassy_time::with_deadline")
    Runs a given future with a deadline time.

[with_timeout](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_timeout.html "fn embassy_time::with_timeout")
    Runs a given future with a timeout.

#### §⟨17⟩Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### §⟨5⟩Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.

# embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a [tick rate](https://lib.rs/crates/embassy-time#readme-tick-rate) feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in ``embassy-time`` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of ```(``1` `/` tick_rate`)` seconds``.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
## Global time driver
The ``time`` module is backed by a global "time driver" specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use ``embassy_time`` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the [``embassy_time_driver``](https://lib.rs/crates/embassy-time-driver) crate.
## Instants and Durations
[``Instant``](https://lib.rs/Instant "`Instant`") represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and [``Duration``](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/?search=Duration "`Duration`") represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you'd expect, like addition and substraction.
## Delays and timeouts
[``Timer``](https://lib.rs/Timer "`Timer`") allows performing async delays. [``Ticker``](https://lib.rs/Ticker "`Ticker`") allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the ``embedded-hal`` delay traits is provided by [``Delay``](https://lib.rs/Delay "`Delay`"), for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
## Wall-clock time
The ``time`` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time ("real life" datetimes like ```2021``-``08``-``24` `13``:``33``:``21```).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of ``embassy_time`` by storing the offset between "seconds elapsed since boot" and "seconds since unix epoch".

# embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a tick rate⟨4⟩ feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in ``embassy-time`` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of ```(``1` `/` tick_rate`)` seconds``.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
## Global time driver
The ``time`` module is backed by a global "time driver" specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use ``embassy_time`` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the ``embassy_time_driver``⟨5⟩ crate.
## Instants and Durations
``Instant``⟨6⟩ represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and ``Duration``⟨7⟩ represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you'd expect, like addition and substraction.
## Delays and timeouts
``Timer``⟨8⟩ allows performing async delays. ``Ticker``⟨9⟩ allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the ``embedded-hal`` delay traits is provided by ``Delay``⟨10⟩, for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
## Wall-clock time
The ``time`` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time ("real life" datetimes like ```2021``-``08``-``24` `13``:``33``:``21```).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of ``embassy_time`` by storing the offset between "seconds elapsed since boot" and "seconds since unix epoch".

proc-macro-error's maintainer seems to be unreachable, with no commits for 2 years, no releases pushed for 4 years, and no activity on the GitLab repo or response to email.

proc-macro-error also depends on `syn 1.x`, which may be bringing duplicate dependencies into dependant build trees.

- [proc-macro2-diagnostics](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/proc-macro2-diagnostics)

## [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#embassy-time)embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a [tick rate](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate) feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in `embassy-time` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of `(1 / tick_rate) seconds`.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#global-time-driver)Global time driver
The `time` module is backed by a global “time driver” specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use `embassy_time` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the [`embassy_time_driver`](https://crates.io/crates/embassy-time-driver) crate.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#instants-and-durations)Instants and Durations
[`Instant`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html "struct embassy_time::Instant") represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and [`Duration`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Duration.html "struct embassy_time::Duration") represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you’d expect, like addition and substraction.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#delays-and-timeouts)Delays and timeouts
[`Timer`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Timer.html "struct embassy_time::Timer") allows performing async delays. [`Ticker`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Ticker.html "struct embassy_time::Ticker") allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the `embedded-hal` delay traits is provided by [`Delay`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Delay.html "struct embassy_time::Delay"), for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#wall-clock-time)Wall-clock time
The `time` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time (“real life” datetimes like `2021-08-24 13:33:21`).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of `embassy_time` by storing the offset between “seconds elapsed since boot” and “seconds since unix epoch”.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#feature-flags)Feature flags
  * `defmt-timestamp-uptime` — Display the time since startup next to defmt log messages. At most 1 `defmt-timestamp-uptime-*` feature can be used. `defmt-timestamp-uptime` is provided for backwards compatibility (provides the same format as `uptime-us`). To use this you must have a time driver provided.
  * `mock-driver` — Create a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes.


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#generic-queue)Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate)Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.

## §⟨4⟩embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a tick rate⟨5⟩ feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in `embassy-time` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of `(1 / tick_rate) seconds`.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
### §⟨6⟩Global time driver
The `time` module is backed by a global “time driver” specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use `embassy_time` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the `embassy_time_driver`⟨7⟩ crate.
### §⟨8⟩Instants and Durations
`Instant`⟨9⟩ represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and `Duration`⟨10⟩ represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you’d expect, like addition and substraction.
### §⟨11⟩Delays and timeouts
`Timer`⟨12⟩ allows performing async delays. `Ticker`⟨13⟩ allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the `embedded-hal` delay traits is provided by `Delay`⟨14⟩, for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
### §⟨15⟩Wall-clock time
The `time` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time (“real life” datetimes like `2021-08-24 13:33:21`).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of `embassy_time` by storing the offset between “seconds elapsed since boot” and “seconds since unix epoch”.
### §⟨16⟩Feature flags
  * `defmt-timestamp-uptime` — Display the time since startup next to defmt log messages. At most 1 `defmt-timestamp-uptime-*` feature can be used. `defmt-timestamp-uptime` is provided for backwards compatibility (provides the same format as `uptime-us`). To use this you must have a time driver provided.
  * `mock-driver` — Create a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes.


#### §⟨17⟩Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### §⟨5⟩Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.
Available tick rates:

## [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#embassy-time)embassy-time
Timekeeping, delays and timeouts.
Timekeeping is done with elapsed time since system boot. Time is represented in ticks, where the tick rate is defined either by the driver (in the case of a fixed-rate tick) or chosen by the user with a [tick rate](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate) feature. The chosen tick rate applies to everything in `embassy-time` and thus determines the maximum timing resolution of `(1 / tick_rate) seconds`.
Tick counts are 64 bits. The default tick rate of 1Mhz supports representing time spans of up to ~584558 years, which is big enough for all practical purposes and allows not having to worry about overflows.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#global-time-driver)Global time driver
The `time` module is backed by a global “time driver” specified at build time. Only one driver can be active in a program.
All methods and structs transparently call into the active driver. This makes it possible for libraries to use `embassy_time` in a driver-agnostic way without requiring generic parameters.
For more details, check the [`embassy_time_driver`](https://crates.io/crates/embassy-time-driver) crate.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#instants-and-durations)Instants and Durations
[`Instant`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html "struct embassy_time::Instant") represents a given instant of time (relative to system boot), and [`Duration`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Duration.html "struct embassy_time::Duration") represents the duration of a span of time. They implement the math operations you’d expect, like addition and substraction.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#delays-and-timeouts)Delays and timeouts
[`Timer`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Timer.html "struct embassy_time::Timer") allows performing async delays. [`Ticker`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Ticker.html "struct embassy_time::Ticker") allows periodic delays without drifting over time.
An implementation of the `embedded-hal` delay traits is provided by [`Delay`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Delay.html "struct embassy_time::Delay"), for compatibility with libraries from the ecosystem.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#wall-clock-time)Wall-clock time
The `time` module deals exclusively with a monotonically increasing tick count. Therefore it has no direct support for wall-clock time (“real life” datetimes like `2021-08-24 13:33:21`).
If persistence across reboots is not needed, support can be built on top of `embassy_time` by storing the offset between “seconds elapsed since boot” and “seconds since unix epoch”.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#feature-flags)Feature flags
  * `defmt-timestamp-uptime` — Display the time since startup next to defmt log messages. At most 1 `defmt-timestamp-uptime-*` feature can be used. `defmt-timestamp-uptime` is provided for backwards compatibility (provides the same format as `uptime-us`). To use this you must have a time driver provided.
  * `mock-driver` — Create a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes.


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#generic-queue)Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#tick-rate)Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.

## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#structs)

[Delay](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Delay.html "struct embassy_time::Delay")
    Type implementing async delays and blocking `embedded-hal` delays.

[Duration](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Duration.html "struct embassy_time::Duration")
    Represents the difference between two [Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html)s

[Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html "struct embassy_time::Instant")
    An Instant in time, based on the MCU’s clock ticks since startup.

[Ticker](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Ticker.html "struct embassy_time::Ticker")
    Asynchronous stream that yields every Duration, indefinitely.

[TimeoutError](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.TimeoutError.html "struct embassy_time::TimeoutError")
    Error returned by [`with_timeout`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_timeout.html "fn embassy_time::with_timeout") and [`with_deadline`](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_deadline.html "fn embassy_time::with_deadline") on timeout.

[Timer](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Timer.html "struct embassy_time::Timer")
    A future that completes at a specified [Instant](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/struct.Instant.html).
## Constants[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#constants)

[TICK_HZ](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/constant.TICK_HZ.html "constant embassy_time::TICK_HZ")
    Ticks per second of the global timebase.
## Traits[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#traits)

[WithTimeout](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/trait.WithTimeout.html "trait embassy_time::WithTimeout")
    Provides functions to run a given future with a timeout or a deadline.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/#functions)

[block_for](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.block_for.html "fn embassy_time::block_for")
    Blocks for at least `duration`.

[with_deadline](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_deadline.html "fn embassy_time::with_deadline")
    Runs a given future with a deadline time.

[with_timeout](https://docs.rs/embassy-time/latest/embassy_time/fn.with_timeout.html "fn embassy_time::with_timeout")
    Runs a given future with a timeout.

To use this you must have a time driver provided.
  * `mock-driver` — Create a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes.


#### §⟨17⟩Generic Queue
By default embassy-time uses a timer queue implementation that is faster but depends on `embassy-executor`. It will panic if you try to await any timer when using another executor.
Alternatively, you can choose to use a “generic” timer queue implementation that works on any executor. To enable it, enable any of the features below.
The features also set how many timers are used for the generic queue. At most one `generic-queue-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 64 timers is used.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `generic-queue-*` feature, to allow the end user to pick.
  * `generic-queue-8` — Generic Queue with 8 timers
  * `generic-queue-16` — Generic Queue with 16 timers
  * `generic-queue-32` — Generic Queue with 32 timers
  * `generic-queue-64` — Generic Queue with 64 timers
  * `generic-queue-128` — Generic Queue with 128 timers


#### §⟨5⟩Tick Rate
At most 1 `tick-*` feature can be enabled. If none is enabled, a default of 1MHz is used.
If the time driver in use supports using arbitrary tick rates, you can enable one `tick-*` feature from your binary crate to set the tick rate. The driver will use configured tick rate. If the time driver supports a fixed tick rate, it will enable one feature itself, so you should not enable one. Check the time driver documentation for details.
When using embassy-time from libraries, you should _not_ enable any `tick-*` feature, to allow the end user or the driver to pick.

## Structs§⟨18⟩

Delay⟨14⟩
    Type implementing async delays and blocking `embedded-hal` delays.

Duration⟨10⟩
    Represents the difference between two Instant⟨9⟩s

Instant⟨9⟩
    An Instant in time, based on the MCU’s clock ticks since startup.

Ticker⟨13⟩
    Asynchronous stream that yields every Duration, indefinitely.

TimeoutError⟨19⟩
    Error returned by `with_timeout`⟨20⟩ and `with_deadline`⟨21⟩ on timeout.

Timer⟨12⟩
    A future that completes at a specified Instant⟨9⟩.

TICK_HZ⟨23⟩
    Ticks per second of the global timebase.

WithTimeout⟨25⟩
    Provides functions to run a given future with a timeout or a deadline.

block_for⟨27⟩
    Blocks for at least `duration`.

with_deadline⟨21⟩
    Runs a given future with a deadline time.

with_timeout⟨20⟩
    Runs a given future with a timeout.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `embassy-time` crate provides timekeeping, delays, and timeouts based on elapsed time since system boot, with high-resolution tick rates configurable up to 2MHz. It supports async delays (`Timer`), periodic delays (`Ticker`), and compatibility with `embedded-hal` delay traits. Key features include a global time driver, customizable tick rates, generic timer queues, and testing utilities like a mock driver.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Feature Flags  
✅ Factual: The `mock-driver` feature in `embassy-time` allows creating a `MockDriver` that can be manually advanced for testing purposes, enabling precise control over time progression during tests.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `mock-driver` feature automatically synchronizes with real-world time during testing, allowing simulated tests to match actual elapsed time.  

---

### Pair 2: Tick Rate  
✅ Factual: The default tick rate in `embassy-time` is 1 MHz, which supports representing time spans of up to approximately 584,558 years without overflow due to its 64-bit tick count representation.  
❌ Counterfactual: The default tick rate in `embassy-time` is 1 kHz, which limits the maximum representable time span to approximately 584 years before overflow occurs.  

---

### Pair 3: Wall-Clock Time  
✅ Factual: `embassy-time` deals exclusively with monotonically increasing tick counts and does not provide direct support for wall-clock time, but wall-clock functionality can be implemented by storing an offset to the Unix epoch.  
❌ Counterfactual: `embassy-time` includes built-in support for wall-clock time, allowing direct manipulation of real-life datetime values like `2021-08-24 13:33:21`.
